results.title: Kingdom of David: the saga of the Israelites [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mitch Wilson, Carl Byker and Oregon Public Broadcasting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Kingdom of David: the saga of the Israelites is the story of one of the most profoundly influential religions, Judaism. This illuminating work features historical re-enactments, as well as interviews with contemporary scholars, to recall the ancient worlds depicted in the Bible. Episode 1. “By the rivers of Babylon”: In 586 BC, the Israelites were exiled in Babylon and seemed destined to disappear; but they fought back by writing a book using Judean stories to explain the present disastrous situations - the Bible. Episode 2. “The Book and the sword”: In 458 BC a scribe named Ezra arrived in Jerusalem from Babylon; gathering the mostly illiterate Judeans together he read the Bible to them. In the following years study of the Bible became an essential part of Jewish life. Episode 3. “The End of days”: When the Roman General Pompeii led his legions into the land of Judea in 63 BC it was the beginning of a clash of cultures that grew into one of the most brutal conflicts in history. Terrorism, political assassination, starvation and crucifixion dominated the landscape, ending with the Roman sack of Jerusalem and the destruction of the Temple in 70 AD. From the aftermath, two new religions rose: rabbinical Judaism and Christianity. Episode 4. “The Gifts of the Jews”: In 132 AD Jewish zealots rebelled against Rome’s legions, forcing them to withdraw from the region. The Romans returned with a vast army, slaughtered nearly 600,000 Jews, changed the name of the region from Judea to Palestine and banned all Jews from Jerusalem. Many Jews fled to distant lands only to face another challenge - a breakaway form of Judaism called Christianity.

results.title: King Zog and the energy crunch
results.brief_description: A puppet animation in which King Zog learns to use his brains instead of scarce energy. The palace sorcerer shows how to make Zog’s palace energy efficient. Featuring the Bob Brown Marionettes.

results.title: King Solomon's mines
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, United Artists Corporation, Sam Zimbalist, Compton Bennett and Andrew Marton
results.brief_description: Perhaps no film in history has ever captured the languid and treacherous beauty of the jungle as has this shot on location spectacular based on H. Rider Haggard’s colossal tale. Stewart Granger, Deborah Kerr and Richard Carlson are thoroughly convincing as three adventurers on a perilous quest in the wilds of darkest Africa. At her beguiling best, Deborah Kerr plays a prim English lady whose husband has vanished into the jungle while searching for the legendary mines of King Solomon. Stewart Granger’s portrayal of Allan Quartermain, “white hunter” and reluctant leader of the danger fraught expedition, is one of the finest roles of his swashbuckling career. “King Solomon’s Mines” offers a colourful palette of action, danger, suspense, drama and romance. Particularly exciting are the extraordinary animal stampedes captured by Robert Sutees’ Oscar winning cinematography.

results.title: King penguins: a study of these birds in captivity
results.brief_description: In this study of King Penguins in their natural surroundings in the Antarctic, and also in the Edinburgh Zoo, the use of the flippers and feet in swimming are shown by underwater slow-motion cinematography. The birds are shown preening themselves, moulting, courting and mating, incubating their eggs, hatching and rearing their young.

results.title: King Oscar story
results.brief_description: Present the year round activities of a large Norwegian fishing company. The fleets follow the seasonal movements of salmon, herring and brisling; various methods of harvesting fish are shown. Factories near the fishing grounds clean, process and can the fish. The company produces its own cans and packaging and maintains a testing laboratory.

results.title: King of the Jews
results.brief_description: Rosenblatt presents an uneasy childhood experience of Jesus as a point of departure for exploring the nexus of fear, fascination and transcendence. A young Jewish boy who grows up fearing Jesus is confronted with the evidence of Christ’s Jewishness. By initially utilising highly saturated colour super-8 home movie and kitsch images from Hollywood Bible epics, King of the Jews, begins as a sardonic commentary on Christian parochialism but ends as a terrifying document of anti-Semitic violence.

results.title: King of the hill
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Gramercy Pictures, Albert Berger, Barbara Maltby, Ron Yerxa and Steven Soderbergh
results.brief_description: After the post-modern dissection of contemporary sexual mores in “Sex, Lies and Videotape” this touching and elegant film, set in 1933 during the height of the Depression, is a wonderful surprise. Aaron (Jesse Bradford) is a young, imaginative Jewish boy whose father is an unemployed salesman and whose mother is hospitalised for tuberculosis. Initially, Aaron is relatively numbed to the devastations of poverty but as his own family descends further into unemployment, the safe confines of his world are slowly stripped away. “King of the Hill” is a homage to the romantic cinema of Capra and Wellman but it does not flinch from expressing the darker undercurrents of poverty. The supporting cast includes Jeroen Krabbe and Lisa Eichhorn as the parents, Karen Allen, Spalding Gray and Elisabeth McGovern. The soundtrack comprises popular songs of the thirties. Based on the Depression memoirs of A.E. Hotchner.

results.title: King of the hill
results.creator_credit: Arthur Barr Productions and Rolf Forsberg
results.brief_description: A human relations film which uses the sterility of a child’s game and the fluidity of a folk dance to illustrate the barren life of the egocentric in a culturally fertile human community which thrives on diversity. Stresses that human beings must be able to grow as individuals, at the same time they grow as organic parts of the community.

results.title: King of the hill
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, William Canning and Donald Brittain
results.brief_description: A look at big league baseball from the inside, from the experience of Ferguson Jenkins, one of the few Canadian players to make the major leagues and winner of the Cy Young Award in 1971 as the National League’s best pitcher. Filmed over the last two seasons Fergie played for the Chicago Cubs before being traded to the Texas Rangers, this story captures the frustrations, the satisfactions and much of the humorous side of this sport. Photographed by David De Volpi, edited by Marrin Canell, written and narrated by Donald Brittain. (Award: Oberhausen)

results.title: King of the children = Hai tzu wang
results.creator_credit: Xi'an Film Studio and Chen Kaige
results.brief_description: The third feature by the director of “Yellow Earth” and “The Big Parade” is set in a remote forest area of Yunnen Province during the Cultural Revolution. A young man from the city, sent to the countryside in a work brigade, is chosen to be a teacher at a village school, despite his own lack of formal education. There he discovers an immense gap between the needs of his students and the culture he is required to offer them. In Mandarin with English subtitles.
